Back in 2000 or 2001, my brothers and I were having a normal day at home. We're triplets. We never knew our real parents, but we had a guardian. We called him dad all the same.
We were outside, and had been playing in a mud pit, building mudcastles, playing around, whatever. Eventually we got thirsty and wanted a snack from the kitchen, but dad wouldn't let us inside because we were too dirty. We were totally filthy. If I recall correctly, I had short, bright blonde hair, and it was totally black from being caked with mud. So we tried washing outside with the garden hose. I got to go first, but midway through, the water pressure dropped to nothing and I couldn't wash any further. There was no way that my brothers could clean off the thick layers of mud they'd put on jumping and rolling around in it. We needed a shower.
Our dad realized this, but we were so dirty that going inside would've ruined the carpet and the walls. He was trying to impress his girlfriend back then, so he was trying to be more organized and took his home's cleanliness really seriously. You couldn't even spot dust inside. However, he had one thing that was dirty as hell: his car, which was basically the receiving end of all his vices. He decided (in what was certainly a flash of genius) that it'd be best if we clean off the mud using the showers at the local pool, which was just a few minutes' ride away.
Let me tell you about his vehicle. This was a real piece of shit. Thirty years old, easily. It went maybe twenty miles an hour, tops, even in our ridiculously flat neighbourhood. There was no way the engine had more than a single horsepower. It smelled of grease and sweat. The tires were basically all flat, except the one good wheel, and the bumper almost non-existent, totally destroyed because he was a pretty careless driver; really clumsy. His vehicle *wobbled* on flat asphalt. Just let that sink in. We got carsick every time.
So anyway, we all bounce into the car -- dad was not exactly a slim guy so he filled up 95% of the space by himself. I sat in the front seat. We pulled out the driveway and had been riding for maybe a minute when we're making a left turn and trying to overtake this red hatchback in front of us, when one of my brothers said that he hadn't yet had his flu shot, and dad turned to look at him, and hushed him and said "I'm driving", and my brother repeated "I need to get my flu shot!" and my dad yelled "I can't juggle that many responsibilities!" and it was in exactly that moment that I realized he had drifted into the wrong lane while overtaking, and we're heading straight for this honking truck!
I flew fifty feet up into the air, maybe more. I don't know. My brothers soared all over the place. It was ironic to be hit by an ice cream truck -- this was exactly the snack I wanted from the kitchen -- and as I flew past the truck window, I got a good look at the driver. Though I was a pretty small kid -- only three months out of the Dunlop Factory -- I could tell that the driver was neither of legal driving age nor a legal permanent resident of the USA.

By and large, I agree that Todd is a dull and weak, two-dimensional character that adds little at the current point in the show. (Note that in Season 3, Todd was moving in and out -- he's getting ready to split and be more independent. That was his character's theme for Season 3: he's finally making more friends and doing his own stuff. Maybe that means he's going evolve as a character. Or that he's going to be written out. That would be a fitting ending to Season 4.)
I want to remark on one thing though: in the start, *most* characters were two-dimensional. Mr. Peanutbutter was a cardboard cutout if you've ever seen one, and Diane was not exactly a paragon of depth. Those two characters have become really filled out by the arc about their marriage. Princess Carolyn was, in the start, also a plain mix of stereotypes, but got several arcs that filled her out.
Practically, here's what I think is going on: I suspect that the writers had to start just like any other TV comedy, with fairly two-dimensional characters and one three-dimensional lead. It quickly became apparent that a significant part of the show's appeal is in the real human tragedy that it tells with thoroughly well-developed and complicated characters. Moving more toward that end, the authors have been filling out the characters one-by-one, and Todd is one of the few major characters left to whom this hasn't happened. (Arguably, he's the only one.)
Todd started out simply as dumb comic relief and as a vehicle to develop/show BoJack's character (we learned a lot about BoJack just from his interactions with Todd). It's tough to plausibly grow a "dumb comic relief" character to loftier heights. Nonetheless, he's come a long way since then, but his character still isn't satisfactory. He doesn't feel human, just kind of farcical. I hope this changes.
----
EDIT: there's probably some significance to Todd being BoJack's best/only friend, and Todd being basically a meaningless shell of a man. Not enough significance to justify the existence of the character, but this seemed noteworthy all the same.

In the late game, you should aim to be basically population-capped the entire time. Your economy and military should be calibrated such that your economic output matches your military production almost exactly. This means: if you find yourself with 10k wood or 8k food to spare, you're doing something wrong. You're either collecting too many resources (in which case: delete some vills) or not making enough military units.
To that end, you need to monitor your economy closely: build new lumber camps if your lumberjacks are walking too far, make sure to have lots of farms queued, and make sure you don't have idle vills. In a team game, you should also be trading (make sure that your trade line is efficient!) as you run out of natural gold.
Strong eco management (in practice, this usually means having about half vills -- e.g. 150 vills in a 300 pop game) and simply spamming military units will let you break 1700 pretty quickly. This is especially the case if you boom reasonably well -- i.e. if you hit pop cap before your opponent. If I'm playing as a pocket, I usually boom to about 100 vills by 28 mins, imp at 30, and then start military creation. You have a large (although temporary) advantage if you hit the late game before your opponents. For booming, the fundamental things are:
* Use your town center hotkey to constantly cycle through your TCs and keep up vill production. * You need 6 farmers to generate enough food to keep up constant vill production in one TC. You need [about 1.5 lumberjacks](https://www.reddit.com/r/aoe2/comments/2qjo3u/how_many_lumberjacks_are_needed_to_keep_farms/) for every 6 farms.
In terms of military management, here are a couple pointers:
* Use lots and lots of buildings. You want to be pop capped all the time, so you'll want your military creation to work as rapidly as possible. Ten barracks, fifteen stables, etc. is not overkill at all. Cycle through all the buildings and queue up a couple units in each. You do not want to be creating 15 paladins in one stable and 0 in the others. (A classic mistake is: too many buildings, too many upgrades, not enough army.) * You need to know your hotkeys for fast queueing; clicking is way too slow. * Set your buildings reasonably close to the front line of the battle so you can reinforce your troops more quickly. Your army should not be running halfway across the map. * Set your spawn points wisely. You do not want to be creating units and running them into your enemy. (A unit will try to reach its spawn destination, even while being attacked -- it doesn't fight back.) You often see people run a hundred skirmishers, one-by-one, into twenty arbalests. All the skirms die, of course. You want to mass up your spawned units into groups before taking them into battle. This usually means setting a spawn point close to, but behind the front line. * Bring vills to the front line so you can build castles, military production buildings, towers, walls, etc. as necessary. Garrisoning in a castle is usually a good idea. NB: Usually you can take resources that you've just conquered, as well. This gives you a further edge. * Watch military idle units. In the course of a long battle, it's very easy to leave units behind (especially trebs, which have to be packed/unpacked). Use the axe symbol on your minimap to see where your military units are. * Always think about counters. Do not send your paladins into halb armies, etc. If you have lots of gold, backing up your army with a couple of bombard cannons is a good idea. Backing your army up with SO is also a good idea, but it's harder because of friendly fire. * In line with counters, think about your army composition. You want to be able to counter their counters. * If possible, raid. If your opponent's eco is not protected by walls, collect 20 hussars/paladins/etc. and send them into your opponent's eco. * If possible, hit their trade line. A bunch of arbs/skirms/HCs in their trade line will absolutely kill their gold income. A castle drop there is a good idea too. * Look for unusual ways to win. Can you use onagers (remember, in the expansions, onagers cut wood) to get through to your opponent's base and raid? If you're on a water map and your opponent has no navy, can you make cannon galleons to wreck their shoreline?
Also, if you're learning, play on normal speed. Learning this stuff on fast is difficult -- it's too overwhelming.
